Award.AwardTitle: Rationality and Stable Rationality of Algebraic Varieties
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is concerned with the study of properties of solutions of systems of nonlinear algebraic equations in many variables. A major open problem in this field is to determine when these solution spaces can be parametrized by independent variables; it can be done for linear or quadratic equations, but is already unknown in degree three. Such algebraic questions have wide-ranging applications, e.g., in data science, optimization, or robotics. Translating this problem into geometry, by focusing on geometric invariants of shapes defined by the systems of equations, opens the door to a plethora of more intuitive techniques: the study of small deformations, or limit shapes. The project also provides research training opportunities for graduate students.

The main goal of the research project is to understand this parametrization property in dimensions 2 and 3, i.e., to study rationality and stable rationality of Del Pezzo surfaces and Fano threefolds over nonclosed fields. Among concrete problems to be addressed are: Obstructions to rationality and stable rationality, such as unramified cohomology, integral decomposition of the diagonal, and Burnside groups; Variation of rationality in families of algebraic varieties, and specialization; Invariants in equivariant birational geometry, in particular, the equivariant Burnside group, as well as its applications to the study of the Cremona group.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was concerned with internal symmetries of higher-dimensional algebraic varieties, i.e., geometric objects defined by algebraic equations. Basic examples are quadrics, defined by the vanishing of a quadratic form in many variables. One of the main problems in this field is to develop criteria for the existence of transformations comparing such varieties with reference varieties, e.g., the standard projective space, compatibly with symmetries. Apart from its intrinsic interest, the study of such equivariant geometries has far-reaching applications in number theory. In technical terms, these fields are known as equivariant birational geometry and geometry over nonclosed fields. 

One of the main outcomes of this project was the introduction of novel invariants in equivariant birational geometry. These invariants assemble in a compact and very explicit form information about the underlying symmetries. This approach allowed to settle several long-standing problems, distinguishing actions of finite groups which were not accessible with classical tools. This yielded surprising examples already for quadric and cubic surfaces and threefolds. As a byproduct, graduate students supported by this award developed powerful computational tools that allowed extensive searches for striking examples and counterexamples.

Specifically, the PI and his collaborators essentially solved the linearizability problem for cubic threefolds, found counterexamples to equivariant versions of rationality conjectures for cubic fourfolds, established foundations of equivariant geometry for stacks, developed algorithms for the computation of the unramified Brauer group, one of the main obstructions to rationality, for quotient spaces under finite groups, developed equivariant versions of the theory of intermediate Jacobians and identified new types of conjugacy classes of involutions in the group of birational transformations of the projective three-space. 

The results of this research were posted on arXiv and presented at major international conferences.
